explanation: Pronounced as a tense, closed [e]. Like the 'a' in English 'say', but without the 'y' glide at the end.
Pronounced as an open, relaxed [ɛ]. Like the 'e' in English 'bed'.
An unaccented 'e' is often silent at the end of words or can be a short, unstressed 'uh' sound [ə] inside words.
To say 'u' [y], make an 'ee' sound while your lips are tightly rounded. 'OU' [u] is simply the English 'oo' sound in 'moon'.
These combinations are usually pronounced as an open 'eh' sound [ɛ], just like È or Ê.
These combinations are pronounced as a closed 'oh' sound [o], like in 'boat'.
This combination is pronounced 'wa' [wa], like in the English word 'watt'.
A unique sound. Say 'eh' [ɛ] but with your lips rounded. Can be more closed [ø] or open [œ].
When a vowel is followed by 'n' or 'm' in the same syllable, the vowel becomes nasal and the 'n' or 'm' is not pronounced.
These usually create the deep, open nasal sound [ɑ̃]. Drop your jaw as if saying 'ah' but direct air through your nose.
These create the rounded nasal sound [ɔ̃]. Make an 'oh' sound through your nose.
These all typically create the nasal sound [ɛ̃]. Make an 'eh' sound through your nose.
Most final consonants (like -s, -t, -d, -x, -p, -z) are silent.
As an exception, the final consonants C, R, F, L are usually pronounced. (Be CaReFuL!)
Pronounced as [k] (hard) before a, o, u. Pronounced as [s] (soft) before e, i, y. A cedilla (ç) makes it always [s].
Pronounced as [g] (hard) before a, o, u. Pronounced as [ʒ] (like 's' in 'treasure') before e, i, y.
Pronounced as [s] at the start of words or when doubled (-ss-). Pronounced as [z] when it is between two vowels.
Almost always pronounced as 'sh' [ʃ], like in English 'shoe'.
Pronounced as [ɲ], like the 'ny' in 'canyon' or Spanish 'ñ'.
'QU' is pronounced [k], like English 'k'. 'GU' before a vowel is pronounced [g], like English 'g' in 'go'. The 'u' is silent.
After a vowel, 'ill' is often pronounced like the 'y' in 'yes' [j].
The French 'r' [ʁ] is made in the back of the throat. It is similar to gargling or the 'ch' in Scottish 'loch'.
'H' is always silent. 'H muet' allows liaison (l'homme). 'H aspiré' acts like a consonant, blocking liaison (le héros).
A normally silent final consonant is pronounced at the start of the next word if that word begins with a vowel.
The final '-s' or '-x' for plural nouns/adjectives is silent. The '-ent' ending for 3rd person plural verbs is also silent.
Stress falls evenly on the last syllable of a word or phrase. There are no strong individual word stresses like in English.
